feed.title: Data Is Plural
feed.subtitle: A weekly newsletter of useful/curious datasets.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.05.10 edition
entry.content:
Prison demographics, more AI incidents, blocked rail crossings, grammatical phenomena, and planetary nomenclature.

Â 

ğŸ“ Reader Evelyn Martin has published explorations of data on electricity demand (DIP 2022.10.05), giant pumpkins (DIP 2022.10.26), and ICE solitary confinement (DIP 2019.06.12) discovered through Data Is Plural. (Have you published something with data you found via DIP? Click here to let me know.)

Â 

Prison demographics. In a recent paper in Nature, Brennan Klein et al. describe how they â€œmanually assembled and validated a dataset covering all 50 US states, the District of Columbia and the Federal Bureau of Prisons to both quantify the widening racial disparity observed during the first year of the COVID-19 pandemic and uncover its plausible causes.â€ Their Dataset on Incarcerated Populations provides the monthly number (or interpolated estimates) of people, by race/ethnicity, in each prison system. The dataset goes back at least to 2010 for most states; for 18 states, it also includes admission/release counts. Related: The Bureau of Justice Statisticsâ€™ annual data on prison demographics, which provide state-level counts by sex but not race/ethnicity. Previously: The Vera Instituteâ€™s Incarceration Trends Dataset (DIP 2019.01.02) and NYU Public Safety Labâ€™s Jail Data Initiative (DIP 2023.04.12). [h/t Shawn Musgrave]

Â 

More AI incidents. The AI, Algorithmic, and Automation Incidents and Controversies initiative, founded by Charlie Pownall in 2019, maintains a repository of such events, as well as related systems (e.g., GPT-4) and datasets (e.g., Labeled Faces in the Wild). The projectâ€™s spreadsheet features 1,000+ entries, each listing a title, type, year, country, sector, operator, purpose, and more â€”Â and linking to more detailed descriptions on AIAAICâ€™s website. Previously: The AI Incident Database (DIP 2023.04.19).

Â 

Blocked rail crossings. â€œAs rail profits soar, blocked crossings force kids to crawl under trains to get to school,â€ a recent investigation by ProPublica and InvestigateTV has found. In addition to on-the-ground reporting, photos, and video, the article cites the Federal Railroad Administrationâ€™s database of blocked crossing complaints. The databaseâ€™s ~70,000 reports, going back to December 2019, each list a crossing ID, street, city, state, railroad, reported incident date, duration, reason, impacts, and additional comments. Related: The FRAâ€™s database of all rail crossings. [h/t Tom Hughes]

Â 

Grammatical phenomena. Grambank, the result of a collaboration involving 100+ linguists, examines a range of grammatical phenomena, â€œfrom word order to verbal tense, nominal plurals, and many other well-studied comparative linguistic variables.â€ The projectâ€™s dataset, available to download and explore online, spans 195 such features across 2,400+ languages and dialects. For instance, hereâ€™s the page for feature GB030, which asks, â€œIs there a gender distinction in independent 3rd person pronouns?â€ [h/t Robin Sloan]

Â 

Planetary nomenclature. The International Astronomical Unionâ€™s Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature â€œprovides a unique system of official names for planetary surface features, natural satellites, dwarf planets, and planetary rings for the benefit of the international science community, educators, and the general public.â€ You can browse, search, and the download the data, as well as view images of their locations. As seen in: Cinzia Bonginoâ€™s The Names on the Moon. [h/t Giuseppe Sollazzo]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send interplanetary feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Listen to the podcast to hear humans. // Swing by the Instagram and/or Mastodon account for multimedia and bonus links.
entry.summary: Prison demographics, more AI incidents, blocked rail crossings, grammatical phenomena, and planetary nomenclature.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.04.26 edition
entry.content:
Drinking water violations, childcare prices, kinship terms, art history allocations, and â€œthe oldest experimental crop field in America.â€

Â 

ğŸ“¬ Reader Robin Moffatt used the drone registration data Ben Welsh obtained via FOIA (DIP 2022.12.21) in a blog post demonstrating lakeFSâ€™ role-based access controls. (Have you published something with data you found via DIP? Fill out this form to let me know.)

Â 

Drinking water violations. Through the Safe Drinking Water Act, the US Environmental Protection Agency sets baseline standards for the countryâ€™s ~150,000 public water systems. Although enforcement is mostly delegated to the states and territories, all monitoring, violation, and enforcement data is reported to the EPA and stored in its Safe Drinking Water Information System. The agency provides bulk downloads of the data, going back decades, plus a search tool and dashboard. As seen in: â€œWhich cities have health issues with their drinking water?â€ (USAFacts). Related: Sara Hughes et al.â€™s Municipal Drinking Water Database, which connects information about 2,000+ municipal water systems to local demographic, government, climate, and political indicators. [h/t Greg Pierce]

Â 

Childcare prices. The National Database of Childcare Prices, launched in January by the Department of Laborâ€™s Womenâ€™s Bureau, â€œis the most comprehensive federal source of childcare prices at the county level.â€ For each county and year from 2008 to 2018, the dataset provides estimates of the median and 75th-percentile weekly cost, disaggregated by provider type and child age. The estimates are calculated from the market surveys the federal Child Care and Development Fund requires participating states to conduct. [h/t Erik Gahner Larsen]

Â 

Kinship terms. Kinbank is a browseable and downloadable database of family-tree nomenclature for 1,000+ spoken languages, across 100+ types of relationships. Examples include ahÃ¤tatum (Akkadian for oneâ€™s younger sister), yerudÃª (Galibi Carib for oneâ€™s husbandâ€™s brotherâ€™s wife), and É—anâ€™Ã¹bÄ (Hausa for oneâ€™s paternal half-brother). As the projectâ€™s team describes in a recent paper, theyâ€™ve collected these â€œkinship terminologiesâ€ mostly from secondary sources, which â€œranged from ethnographies and grammars, to simpler descriptions like wordlistsâ€; those sources â€œare primarily in Roman script [â€¦] and can contain transcription inconsistencies across languages.â€

Â 

Art history allocations. For her undergraduate thesis, â€œQuantifying Art Historical Narratives,â€ Holland Stam measured the amount of space (in text and in images) devoted to each artwork and artist in 25 editions of two major art history textbooks: Gardnerâ€™s Art Through the Ages and Jansonâ€™s History of Art. Stamâ€™s thesis repository includes the measurement data, which also indicates each artistâ€™s nationality, gender, race, and ethnicity. Related: An R package for the data. As seen in: â€œResampling to understand gender in #TidyTuesday art history data,â€ a post and screencast by Julia Silge.

Â 

The Morrow Plots. The University of Illinoisâ€™ Morrow Plots, established in 1876, â€œare the oldest experimental crop field in America and the second oldest in the world.â€ An interdisciplinary team has compiled, cleaned, and standardized the experimentâ€™s archival records (such as this notebook). For each year and plot, their dataset lists the crop, date of planting, treatment plan, amount of various substances applied, yield per acre, and more.

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send high-yield feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Listen to the podcast to hear humans. // Swing by the Instagram and/or Mastodon account for visuals.
entry.summary: Drinking water violations, childcare prices, kinship terms, art history allocations, and â€œthe oldest experimental crop field in America.â€

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.04.19 edition
entry.content:
Municipal zoning rules, AI incidents, state bill trajectories, rare-earth mining projects, and â€œpirate radioâ€ enforcement.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ Reader Idil used the FDICâ€™s list of failed banks (DIP 2023.03.15) to analyze and visualize trends in those failures by year and state, for Moneyzine. (Have you published something with data you found via DIP? Fill out this form to let me know.)

Â 

Municipal zoning rules. Matt Mleczko and Matthew Desmond, of Princetonâ€™s Eviction Lab (DIP 2018.04.18), have developed a method for extracting structured information from the text of local zoning regulations. Their National Zoning and Land Use Database covers 2,600+ cities, towns, and other municipalities â€” a sample drawn from the Wharton Residential Land Use Regulatory Indexâ€™s prior, survey-based research. The database includes dozens of indicators, such as whether the rules specify annual limits on several types of permits, allow any accessory dwelling units, require various review-board approvals, impose parking space minimums, and more. These factors then feed into the authorsâ€™ Zoning Restrictiveness Index, which they calculate at a municipal and metro-area level.

Â 

AI incidents. The AI Incident Database â€œis dedicated to indexing the collective history of harms or near harms realized in the real world by the deployment of artificial intelligence systems.â€ The open-source project is â€œmanaged in a participatory manner,â€ with a board of directors, submissions from the public, and a team of reviewers guided by a set of definitions and decision criteria. So far, it has cataloged 500+ incidents and 2,500+ reports, which you can search and filter by entity, category, date, and other facets. You can also download full snapshots of the database. [h/t Sasha Anderson]

Â 

State bill trajectories. Political scientist Alex Garlick has published a dataset categorizing billsâ€™ trajectories in state legislatures. It follows each proposed lawâ€™s journey along 23 possible steps, which range from â€œFirst Reading (first chamber)â€ to â€œBill enacted.â€ The dataset spans more than 1 million bills tracked by OpenStates (DIP 2020.09.30), with full coverage for all 50 states for 2011â€“18 and partial coverage for some earlier and later years. Read more: â€œBicameralism Hinges on Legislative Professionalism,â€ Garlick and Adam R. Brownâ€™s recent paper (and preprint) using this data.

Â 

Rare-earth mining. Shuang-Liang Liu et al. have compiled a dataset of 146 mining projects targeting rare-earth elements, which serve as â€œcritical raw materials in many low-carbon technologies.â€ The dataset lists each projectâ€™s name, company, location, status, deposit type, estimated tonnage of deposits, element composition, and other details sourced from â€œcompany annual reports and public presentations, government reports, and papers in various scientific journals.â€

Â 

â€œPirate radioâ€ enforcement. The Federal Communications Commission publishes a dashboard and dataset of its â€œpirate radioâ€ enforcement actions, part of the agencyâ€™s crackdown against the â€œunauthorized transmission of radio frequency signals on the frequencies in or adjacent to the FM and AM radio bands.â€ The 38 entries list the entity targeted, state/territory, radio frequency, enforcement type, date issued, and penalty amount. They go back to early 2020, when Congress passed the PIRATE Act. Related: Congressional acronym abuse, 1973-2013. [h/t Jon Keegan]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send unauthorized feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Listen to the podcast to hear humans. // Swing by the Instagram and/or Mastodon account for visuals.
entry.summary: Municipal zoning rules, AI incidents, state bill trajectories, rare-earth mining projects, and â€œpirate radioâ€ enforcement.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.04.12 edition
entry.content:
Jail rosters, sanctions enforcement, border surveillance, flash flooding in urban England, and Dutch textile shipments.

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ Have you published something (â† an intentionally broad term) based on data you discovered through Data Is Plural? Let me know by responding to this email or by filling out this form. Iâ€™ll aim to share your work here and via DIPâ€™s new Mastodon and Instagram accounts.

Â 

Jail rosters. The NYU Public Safety Labâ€™s Jail Data Initiative has built a fleet of web scrapers to gather and process daily roster data from 1,000+ US city and county jails. The projectâ€™s aggregate metrics include the number of people in these jails each day, the daily numbers of people newly incarcerated and released, and how long people have been held (among those released). You can filter and download these counts by age, gender, and race. Profiles of individual jails also list the most common charges and the overall demographics of people held there. The time frames available vary by jail, but mostly begin in 2020 or 2021. You can also apply for access to person-level records. [h/t Adam Vine + Orion Taylor]

Â 

Sanctions enforcement. Political scientists Bryan R. Early and Keith A. Preble have assembled a dataset of the US Office of Foreign Assets Controlâ€™s sanctions-related penalties, settlements, and findings of violation since 2003. To do so, they combed through the agencyâ€™s mostly-PDF-based archive of these enforcement actions. Each of the datasetâ€™s 1,000+ entries indicates the action date, type, and monetary amount; entity name, type, location, and sector; the specific sanctions programs violated; and more. Previously: OFACâ€™s sanctions lists (DIP 2018.02.21) and OpenSanctions (DIP 2021.09.08).

Â 

Border surveillance. The Electronic Frontier Foundation has constructed a map and dataset of 340+ Customs and Border Protection surveillance towers along the US-Mexico border. â€œCompiled using public records, satellite imagery, road trips, and even exploration in virtual reality,â€ the dataset indicates each towerâ€™s location, name, type, and vendor; it also links to sources and satellite imagery. Separate entries list potential future towers proposed by CBP and automated license plate readers at CBP checkpoints. [h/t Corin Faife]

Â 

Flash flooding in urban England. ClimateNodeâ€™s Helen Jackson has created a dataset and series of interactive maps of recent summertime flash flooding in urban England. To construct the dataset, Jackson â€œanalysed approximately 17,400 articles about flooding from around 300 newspaper websites,â€ and then used natural language processing to â€œextract the names of streets, buildings and other places affectedâ€ â€” some 2,800+ locations in all, corresponding to 56 flooding events since 2010. [h/t Giuseppe Sollazzo]

Â 

Dutch textile shipments. The Dutch Textile Trade Project â€œaims to understand the circulation of globally-sourced textiles on Dutch ships around the world in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries by examining data drawn from trade records alongside samples of textiles and visual culture depicting textiles in use.â€ The 22,000+ entries in the projectâ€™s main dataset each represent a shipment from one port to another; they indicate the textile type, quantity, and value, shipment date, supplier, and more. [h/t Dan Bouk]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send fibrous feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Listen to the podcast to hear humans. // Swing by the Instagram and/or Mastodon account for multimedia.
entry.summary: Jail rosters, sanctions enforcement, border surveillance, flash flooding in urban England, and Dutch textile shipments.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.04.05 edition
entry.content:
Treasury transactions, more than 200 million European buildings, 911 service areas, lists of medical codes, and Midwestern mollusks.

Â 

ğŸ¤ In case you missed last weekâ€™s announcement: Iâ€™ve launched a Data Is Plural podcast, and itâ€™s available in your favorite podcast app.

Â 

ğŸ“¸ Looking for something more ~visual~ from Data Is Plural? In the continued spirit of trying new things, Iâ€™ve created an Instagram account and Mastodon account, where Iâ€™ll be sharing screenshots and other multimedia bits that donâ€™t fit into the newsletterâ€™s text-only format.

Â 

Treasury transactions. The US Treasuryâ€™s Daily Treasury Statement dataset paints a near-real-time picture of the federal governmentâ€™s purse. The eight tables provide data on â€œoperating cash balance, deposits and withdrawals of cash, public debt transactions, federal tax deposits, income tax refunds issued,â€ and more. The table of deposits and withdrawals, for example, indicates the total value (rounded to the nearest $1 million) of transactions each day, by type and category (e.g., â€œEconomic Recovery Programs,â€ â€œDefense Vendor Payments,â€ etc.). The records, available to download in bulk or via API, go back to October 2005. As seen in: â€œCan a billionaire die without anyone noticing? The mystery behind a remarkable $7 billion tax payment.â€ (Tim Fernholz, Quartz). [h/t Walt Hickey]

Â 

European buildings. EUBUCCO is a â€œdatabase of individual building footprints for 200+ million buildings across the 27 European Union countries and Switzerland, together with three main attributes â€“ building type, height and construction year â€“ included for respectively 45%, 74%, 24% of the buildings.â€ The researchers, who describe their methodology in a recent paper, collected and standardized the information from 50 open government datasets and OpenStreetMap. They then â€œperform[ed] extensive validation analyses to assess the quality, consistency and completeness of the data in every country.â€ You can browse the data online, download it, and access the underlying code.

Â 

911 service areas. Public Safety Answering Points (PSAPs) are, essentially, the call centers to which 911 calls are routed. A while ago, the US government hired a contractor to compile a dataset of the service area boundaries for each of the countryâ€™s PSAPs, â€œthe geographic area within which a 911 call placed using a landline is answered at the associated PSAP.â€ Although some of that information has likely changed since the datasetâ€™s publication in 2009, the records may still be useful for certain purposes. Related: The FCCâ€™s 911 Master PSAP Registry, which doesnâ€™t include service boundaries but does provide the name, state, county, and ID of 6,000+ primary PSAPs, plus 2,700+ PSAPs listed as â€œsecondary,â€ â€œduplicate,â€ or â€œorphaned.â€ [h/t Maddy Varner + Mike Thompson]

Â 

Lists of medical codes. OpenCodelists is â€œan open platform for creating and sharing codelists of clinical terms and drugs,â€ built by the University of Oxfordâ€™s OpenSAFELY team. The platform supports several coding systems, including ICD-10 and SNOWMED CT. The lists can refer to groups of symptoms, diagnoses, medications, and more. Public lists note their creators and coding system; you can view each listâ€™s codes online, or download them as a CSV. [h/t Ben Goldacre]

Â 

Midwestern mollusks. The Illinois Natural History Surveyâ€™s mollusk collection contains 500,000+ specimens, cataloged into 90,000+ lots, some gathered more than a century ago. â€œThe collection is strong in freshwater mussels (Unionoida), freshwater and terrestrial snails from the Midwestern U.S. and cone shells (Conoidea),â€ as well as â€œfreshwater bivalves and gastropods from the Southeastern U.S., Central, and South America.â€ For each lot, the collectionâ€™s dataset lists the genus, species, number of specimens, date and location collected, and more. Related: INHSâ€™s other collections. [h/t Meredith Broussard]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send freshwater feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Listen to the podcast to hear humans. // Swing by the Instagram and/or Mastodon account for multimedia.
entry.summary: Treasury transactions, more than 200 million European buildings, 911 service areas, lists of medical codes, and Midwestern mollusks.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.03.29 edition
entry.content:
Local public meetings, health workers, Kremlin posts, carbon capture projects, and Milan drinking fountains.

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ Surprise! Say hello to Data Is Plural: The Podcast. The first season is now available in its entirety â€” five concise episodes, each based on data previously featured in this newsletter. This is my first time creating a podcast, and I still have lots to learn. So please do let me know what you think; critiques and suggestions for improvement particularly appreciated. And a big, hearty thanks to this seasonâ€™s guests (Andy, Mattie, Pablo, Irena, Vikram), who generously agreed to be interviewed for a podcast that, at the time, was just a vague idea.

Â 

Local public meetings. LocalView, developed by Soubhik Barari and Tyler Simko, â€œis the largest dataset of local government public meetings â€” the central policy-making process in American local government â€” as they are captured on video.â€ In a recent paper, the authors describe how they built the dataset, which is based on 130,000+ YouTube-hosted videos of such meetings in 1,000+ US cities and counties, covering the years 2006 to 2022. The dataset lists each meetingâ€™s date, jurisdiction, and government body (e.g., municipal council, school board, etc.), plus the videoâ€™s ID, title, channel, transcript, and more. [h/t Chris Goodman]

Â 

Health workers. The World Health Organizationâ€™s Global Health Workforce Statistics database presents annual, national estimates of the number of medical doctors, nursing and midwifery professionals, community health workers, and several other types of health personnel. The estimates come from the WHOâ€™s National Health Workforce Accounts system, national censuses, labor force surveys, and other sources. For medical doctors, the estimates span nearly 200 countries, with the majority having estimates as recent as 2020 or 2021. Twenty countriesâ€™ estimates go back to the 1960s (and, for Spain, all the way back to 1952). [h/t Datasketch]

Â 

Kremlin posts. Giorgio Comaiâ€™s â€œtext as data & data in the textâ€ project â€œaims at facilitating structured analysis of on-line contents related to conflicts in the post-Soviet space by providing easier access to relevant datasets and tools.â€ Those datasets include the URL, title, text, date, and other metadata of all posts published on the Kremlinâ€™s English-language website since the year 2000; on the Kremlinâ€™s Russian-language website; and by Zavtra since late 1996. Previously: Foreign ministry statements (DIP 2022.03.09). [h/t EDJNet]

Â 

Carbon capture projects. The National Energy Technology Laboratory maintains a map and dataset of carbon capture and storage projects â€œactive, proposed, and terminatedâ€ in 30+ countries since the 1970s. The latest version of the dataset includes 400+ entries, slightly more than are on the map. It lists each projectâ€™s name, company, location, date, type, scope, magnitude, status, technology, cost, summary, and other details. As seen in: â€œWhat is carbon capture and storage? Where is it happening in the US?â€ (USAFacts).

Â 

Milan drinking fountains. Milanâ€™s government publishes a dataset of 600+ local vedovelle, the distinctive (green, cast iron, dragon-headed) drinking fountains that dot the city. The dataset provides each fountainâ€™s coordinates, municipal zone, and neighborhood. As seen in: â€œTutto sulle fontanelle di Milano,â€ with a map of the locations, by Il Postâ€™s Isaia Invernizzi.

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send potable feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions.
entry.summary: Local public meetings, health workers, Kremlin posts, carbon capture projects, and Milan drinking fountains.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.03.22 edition
entry.content:
Civilian harm in Ukraine, aid for Ukraine, municipal incorporations, political podcasts, and stop signs.

Â 

Civilian harm in Ukraine. Researchers at Bellingcat and contributors to its Global Authentication Project have assembled a map and dataset of 1,000+ incidents â€œthat have resulted in potential civilian impact or harm since Russia began its invasion of Ukraine.â€ They include incidents â€œwhere rockets or missiles struck civilian areas,â€ â€œwhere attacks have resulted in the destruction of civilian infrastructure,â€ and/or where visual evidence depicts civilian injuries or â€œimmobile civilian bodies.â€ The information, collected from public sources and vetted by Bellingcat, includes each incidentâ€™s date, location, description, sources, type of area affected, and type of weapon system (if known). [h/t Philip Bump]

Â 

Aid for Ukraine. Christoph Trebesch et al.â€™s Ukraine Support Tracker â€œlists and quantifies military, financial and humanitarian aid to Ukraine in the context of the Russia-Ukraine war.â€ The 1,400+ entries in the trackerâ€™s dataset include contributions and commitments from 40 governments, plus several European Union institutions. (It does not include aid from NGOs and other non-state entities.) Each entry indicates the country, announcement date, type of aid, total value, description, sources, and more. The trackerâ€™s next update is scheduled for March 29.

Â 

Municipal incorporations. Christopher B. Goodman, a professor of public administration, has consulted a range of state-level sources to compile a dataset listing the year of incorporation for 18,000+ municipalities in the United States. The dataset, which covers nearly 96% of all active municipalities, also provides each placeâ€™s name, state, coordinates, canonical ID in the Census, and more. Read more: In a Twitter thread, Goodman explains why he undertook the effort and shares a couple of visualizations. [h/t Maggie Lee]

Â 

Political podcasts. The Popular Political Podcast Dataset, developed by the Brookings Institutionâ€™s Valerie Wirtschafter and Chris Meserole, covers 50,000+ episodes from 100+ â€œprominent political podcast seriesâ€ â€” the latter based on Apple Podcastsâ€™ popularity rankings and its â€œYou Might Also Likeâ€ recommendations. Updated daily and explorable online, the dataset provides each episodeâ€™s name, description, air date, and URL, plus the series name, partisan leaning, and Apple Podcasts category.

Â 

Stop signs. The City of Los Angeles publishes the location and orientation of 50,000+ local stop signs (plus a few yield signs). Other cities offering similar datasets include Houston, San Francisco, Detroit, Topeka, Menlo Park, and London, Ontario. Related: OpenStreetMapâ€™s dataset features nearly 1.4 million stop signs located across the world. [h/t Matt Stiles]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send octagonal feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions.
entry.summary: Civilian harm in Ukraine, aid for Ukraine, municipal incorporations, political podcasts, and stop signs.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.03.15 edition
entry.content:
Recent bank financials, historical bank financials, policy categorizations, irrigation water use, and the market for X-Men.

Â 

Bank financials, 1976â€“present. The Federal Financial Institutions Examination Councilâ€™s National Information Center â€œprovides comprehensive financial and structure information on banks and other institutions for which the Federal Reserve has a supervisory, regulatory, or research interest.â€ Its datasets include quarterly financial statements for bank holding companies, going back to 2016, plus detailed attributes of all active banks, 150,000+ banks closed since the mid-1930s (including Silicon Valley Bank), and 160,000+ bank branches. The agency also provides bank financials in the form of â€œcall reportsâ€ going back to 2001. Earlier call reports, going back to 1976, are available from the Chicago Fed. Related: The FDICâ€™s list of failed banks since October 2000. [h/t Sergio Correia]

Â 

Bank financials, 1867â€“1904. Federal Reserve economists Sergio Correia and Stephan Luck have compiled a dataset of â€œannual national bank balance sheets for more than 7,000 unique national banks, covering the years 1867 to 1904.â€ They did so by â€œcombining optical character recognition (OCR) techniques with modern layout separation techniques,â€ which allowed them to extract information from scans of the Office of the Comptroller of the Currencyâ€™s annual reports to Congress. The data include asset and liability subtotals, receivership dates, city-level variables, and more. Related: Correia and Luck describe their methodology in a recent paper and open-access preprint.

Â 

Policies, categorized. The Comparative Agendas Project â€œassembles and codes information on the policy processes of governments from around the world,â€ categorizing them into 20+ topics (e.g., â€œCivil Rightsâ€) and 200+ subtopics (e.g., â€œHandicap Discriminationâ€). It â€œactively monitors thirty different data series,â€ which you can download and explore online, â€œall coded by this same predictable, reliable coding system.â€ Previously: CAP categorizations for a decade of NYT front-page stories (DIP 2018.04.25). [h/t E.J. Fagan]

Â 

Irrigation by county and crop. P. J. Ruess et al. have developed annual, county-level estimates of irrigation water use for 20 crop groups between 2008 and 2020. The calculations draw on water use data from the US Geological Survey, as well as high-resolution data on crop locations, climate, and more. They generate estimates for surface water withdrawals, groundwater withdrawals, and nonrenewable groundwater depletion, making the findings â€œthe first national-scale assessment of irrigation by crop, water source, and year.â€ [h/t Mike Stucka]

Â 

The market for X-Men. Anderson Evansâ€™s Mutant Moneyball project uses comic book market data to explore the financial value of individual X-Men characters. The projectâ€™s dataset provides decade-by-decade statistics for 26 members of the team, drawn from sales histories and pricing guides, as well as a matrix indicating the issues in which each character appeared.

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send marvelous feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Advertise in Data Is Plural.
entry.summary: Recent bank financials, historical bank financials, policy categorizations, irrigation water use, and the market for X-Men.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.03.08 edition
entry.content:
Government contracting data, debt-to-income ratios, changes of address, decades of UK prices, and shows cut short.

Â 

Government contracting data, cataloged. The nonprofit Open Contracting Partnership has launched a registry of government procurement datasets that use its Open Contracting Data Standard (featured in DIP 2020.02.26). The registry contains 100+ entries so far, across 50+ countries â€” from Argentinaâ€™s national roads authority and the city of Buenos Aires to Zambiaâ€™s Public Procurement Authority. You can filter the listings by dataset recency, update frequency, and the data types included (parties, awards, documents, amendments, et cetera). [h/t Georg Neumann]

Â 

Debt-to-income ratios. The US Federal Reserve generates quarterly statistics estimating the median ratio of household debt to income in each state, county, and metro area. The published maps and datasets, which go back to 1999, donâ€™t include precise figures, but rather place each geographic unit into one of ten ranges. The income calculations come from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, while the debt estimates (which do not include student loans) come from the New York Fed Consumer Credit Panel, â€œan anonymized 5 percent random sample of Americans with credit files at the credit reporting bureau Equifax.â€ As seen in: â€œDebt and Inequalityâ€ (American Inequality).

Â 

Â 

Changes of address. In the â€œFrequently Requested Recordsâ€ section of its online FOIA library, the US Postal Service provides datasets counting how many individuals, families, and businesses have registered for the agencyâ€™s change-of-address service, by month and ZIP code. The datasets tally the moves originating from a given ZIP code separately from those destined for it, although moves within the same ZIP code are counted on both sides of the ledger. Related: The companies to which USPS sells mover-level data. [h/t Tim Henderson]

Â 

Decades of UK prices. In January 2023, the UKâ€™s Office for National Statistics collected 139,000+ price quotes from thousands of stores and across hundreds of products, from â€œA4 PRINTER PAPER (500 REAM)â€ to â€œYORKSHIRE PUDDING FROZENâ€. The agency has collected this kind of price-quote data for decades, using it to calculate inflation and price indices. Economist Richard Davies has aggregated the data going back to 1988 and standardized it, correcting misrecorded prices, offsetting measurement changes, among other efforts described in a 2021 working paper.

Â 

Shows cut short. IsItCutShort.com provides a searchable list of television shows that were canceled (e.g., Knight Rider), ended on a cliffhanger (The Sopranos), or both (Rubicon). The database provides each seriesâ€™s title, cliffhanger and cancellation status, IMDB identifier, and occasional extra notes. A handful of the 130+ entries fit another category: shows that â€œended without a cliffhanger, but more show content exists outside the show itself.â€ [h/t Dan Brady]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send unrenewed feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Place an ad in Data Is Plural.
entry.summary: Government contracting data, debt-to-income ratios, changes of address, decades of UK prices, and shows cut short.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.03.01 edition
entry.content:
Congressional votes and ideology, EPA-regulated facilities, programming languages, 20th-century occupations, and coconut thumps.

Â 

Congressional votes and ideology. The Voteview project â€œallows users to view every congressional roll call vote in American history,â€ and places those votes in the context of ideology estimates along a liberal-to-conservative spectrum. The core estimates come from DW-NOMINATE, a method developed by the projectâ€™s directors emeritus, Keith T. Poole and Howard Rosenthal. Voteviewâ€™s bulk data includes ideology estimates for every member of the House and Senate since 1789, every vote taken in either chamber, and every memberâ€™s position on those votes. [h/t Philip Bump]

Â 

EPA-regulated facilities. The US Environmental Protection Agencyâ€™s Facility Registry System â€œprovides Internet access to a single source of comprehensive information about facilities, sites or places subject to environmental regulations or of environmental interest.â€ It includes each entityâ€™s name, type, location, industry, regulatory programs, and more. That information, which spans millions of facilities, is â€œsubjected to rigorous verification and data management quality assurance procedures.â€ The records also provide facilitiesâ€™ ID numbers from other EPA systems, such as the agencyâ€™s Risk Management Program database featured in last weekâ€™s edition. [h/t Michael Allen]

Â 

Programming languages. PLDB is a database that describes several thousand programming languages, file formats, communications protocols, and other related concepts. Its downloads, available in several formats, provide information on the languagesâ€™ years announced, technical features, creators, countries and communities of origin, relevant books and URLs, popularity metrics, and more. [h/t Derek M. Jones]

Â 

20th-century occupations. Between 1939 and 1991, the US government published several iterations of the now-discontinued Dictionary of Occupational Titles, a precursor to the O*NET database (DIP 2017.09.27). The dictionaries included job descriptions, classification codes, and cross-references, but are mostly available only as scans. So Shahad Althobaiti et al. organized the manual transcription of five major editions into structured text files. A random sample of 1939â€™s titles: punch-press operator, seam dampener, base brander, box pleater, and necktie finisher.

Â 

Thump, thump, coconut. â€œTraditionally,â€ in the Philippines, â€œcoconuts are classified into their maturity levels manually,â€ June Anne Caladcad and Eduardo Piedad Jr. write. â€œTraders often use their fingernails, knuckles, or the blunt end of the knife to tap the coconuts before assessing the sounds produced.â€ The authors and their colleagues have developed hardware and software to emulate that process, and used it to collect acoustic signal data from 129 premature, mature, and overmature coconuts, each mechanically knocked on each of its three ridges.

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send overmature feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Learn how to place an ad in Data Is Plural.
entry.summary: Congressional votes and ideology, EPA-regulated facilities, programming languages, 20th-century occupations, and coconut thumps.
